I bow my head to the most honored one in the three realms, the auspicious and immaculate one who has exhausted all defilements,
The foolish are submerged in delusion and afflictions, but you are able to rescue them with impartial compassion.
Relying on the Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä, the vast ocean of sÅ«tras,
I have compiled these gÄthÄs to serve as the eyes of the world.
One should give rise to pure faith, be diligent and not negligent,
Turn away from the six sense objects, and cultivate subtle wisdom.
Take delight in giving, upholding precepts, patience, and various meditative absorptions,
And with the four immeasurables, benefit and bring joy to all sentient beings.
If one is distracted and negligent, gives rise to violent evil views,
And always speaks false words, one will fall into hell.
If one is stingy and jealous, and stays far away from good dharmas,
And delights in harming sentient beings, one will definitely fall into the realm of hungry ghosts.
If one destroys the true Dharma, is foolish, attached to defiled desires,
And indulges in food, drink, and sleep, one will obtain the retribution of being an animal.
The three kinds of body, speech, and mind create all kinds of unwholesomeness,
And are bound by karma, which increases again and again.
Thus, those foolish people go on and on without rest,
But the wise ones who cultivate well will attain the bliss of tranquility.
Knowing that this is the result of karma, one abandons heedlessness,
And with wisdom makes distinctions - this goodness is unsurpassed.
Always delighting in practicing generosity, firmly upholding pure precepts,
Having compassion for all sentient beings, enabling their wishes to be fulfilled,
Being in accord with kindness and compassion, not giving rise to expectations,
In order to embrace others, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
Liberating from greed and hatred, knowing contentment and avoiding faults,
Loving and caring for sentient beings, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
With equality and straightforwardness, without thoughts of enemies or friends,
Forever escaping from all evil destinies, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
Endowed with all dignified conduct, skillfully expounding the Dharma equally,
Free from stinginess, jealousy, and faults, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
Delighting in serving teachers and elders, upholding precepts and cultivating various concentrations,
Clearly understanding the characteristics of offenses and merits, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
Arousing courageous and vigorous effort, sitting in meditation or reciting scriptures,
Speaking lovingly without flattery, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
In time and place, either acting or resting,
All should be skillfully understood, one will definitely attain accomplishment.
Non-anger subdues anger, patience removes violence and evil,
The right Dharma abandons unrighteousness, light dispels darkness,
Truth dispels falsehood, tranquility destroys slander,ğŸ”½Compassion stops slander, non-binding liberates from bondage,
Compassion stops killing, giving brings an end to the defilement of stinginess.
Using purity and goodness to counteract improper thoughts,
Using wisdom to illuminate ignorance, impermanence destroys the attachment to permanence.
Just as the sun wanes and the moon diminishes, change and flow are originally like this,
One should contemplate well oneself, observe and depart from wrong desires.
The eightfold noble path is the cause, able to transcend all evil destinies,
Abiding in the four fearlessnesses, able to subdue all fears,
Right mindfulness removes false thoughts, superior wisdom destroys wrong wisdom,
Delighting in dwelling in the araá¹‡ya, simple and free from greed and desire.
Just as among all mountains, Mount Sumeru is the most supreme,
Just as the great ocean is deep and vast, able to give birth to various treasures;
Just like the bright light of the sun outshines all the stars.
Non-arising stops arising, like fire burning dry wood,
Also like wonderful food and drink, able to remove hunger and thirst.
Like a lion's advance and retreat, able to subdue all beasts,
Contentment cuts off greedy seeking, fearlessness is also like this.
Compassion is universally praised in the world, abandoning it all despise,
Sloth and stupidity, diligence can eliminate.
If there is a violent and evil person, unjustly slandering and harming,
The wise with sincere words, patiently enduring can eliminate it.
The gods defeat the asuras, due to believing and delighting in the true Dharma,
The Buddha appears in the world, able to restrain all non-Buddhist paths.
If a person skillfully expounds the Dharma, enabling others to understand,
He becomes a guide for the assembly, leading them to a place of peace and security,
Pointing out the correct path to enlightenment, ultimately causing them to enter,
Forever severing the bonds of delusion in the perilous path of birth and death.
This Dharma is unsurpassed, not spoken by worldly people;
If there are those who hear it, they will be able to cross the ocean of existence.
If there are wise people who diligently cultivate it here,
There are four kinds of fields of merit that can give rise to all good fruits.
If one upholds the Buddha's teachings, one will attain complete faculties;
If one does not give rise to a mind of delight, one will later only regret and be distressed.
If a person always pursues and indulges in the five desires,
Fondly attached to wife and children, one will fall into an evil realm.
Giving rise to improper thoughts, accumulating all faults,
All arise from one's own mind, bound by false thoughts.
This mind is difficult to subdue, often grasping at objects of desire.
If one can skillfully control it, one will attain coolness and peace.
This mind is like a vicious horse, subdued by the true Dharma.
Having heard it, one should remember it and contemplate it again and again.
If a person hears the true Dharma, having heard it, they will understand it all,
Giving rise to wholesome roots, far from all faults.
Because of hearing the true Dharma, the mind is pure and undefiled,
Giving rise to leaping and joyful exuberance, increasing bright wisdom.
Because of hearing the true Dharma, one does not create many offenses,
Knowing that karmic results are not empty, one will attain the path of enlightenment.
Because of hearing the true Dharma, one knows the merits of the Buddha,
The Dharma is the cause of liberation, this is the true wise one.
By listening to the true Dharma, one knows the nature of phenomena is eternally abiding,
Therefore, one should single-mindedly diligently practice in action.
By listening to the true Dharma, one is liberated from the ocean of cyclic existence,
Cutting off various kinds of craving, one will realize the ultimate truth.
By listening to the true Dharma, one awakens to the characteristics of arising and ceasing,
Endowed with the four kinds of causes and conditions, one will clearly and thoroughly understand.
By listening to the true Dharma, one understands the aggregates, sense bases, and elements,
Corresponding with the characteristics of arising and ceasing, causing correct wisdom to manifest.
These three kinds of afflictions are the basis for cyclic existence,
Delighting in listening to the true Dharma, one should cut them off and completely eliminate them.
If one delights in listening to much, there is no higher state in the world,
In moving and unmoving dharmas, one thoroughly investigates their origins.
When this person's life ends, they will have no more worries or fears,
Well understanding that true Dharma, they do not give rise to even the slightest suffering.
Able to burn the fuel of afflictions with the fire of right wisdom,
Because of delighting in much learning, they will not suffer again in the future.
If one draws near to much learning, then peaceful and blissful joy arises,
Free from the burning of heedlessness, this is the root of what is good.
One should serve the elders and delight in their explanations,
Escaping the causes of old age and death, one attains the abode of true permanence.
Fully understanding all dharmas, liberated from the defilements of obstructions,
Drawing out the mind of enlightenment, much learning is supreme.
If one practices near much learning, delighting in cultivating right wisdom,
One should with body, speech, and mind, respect and always revere it.
If one delights in much learning, well abiding in the nature of dharmas,
Firmly and diligently practicing, one can cross over the ocean of the three existences.
If a person has much learning, they are endowed with all kinds of wealth.
Even if one is wealthy without learning, they are foolish and ignorant, the same as a poor person.
If a person lacks the wealth of the Dharma and is far from a teacher,
They vainly bear that physical form, always harboring worry and shame.
If one is close to bad friends, they give rise to negligence and laziness,
Just like sowing seeds in vain in a barren field.
The learned are endowed with the Dharma eye, although blind they are still enlightened,
Those without eyes and without much learning are the dull and dim ones.
If one is far from the true Dharma and relies on non-Dharma,
It is like abandoning a good doctor while seeking to cure a serious illness.
The Dharma has no limit, one must accumulate learning to gradually awaken to it,
Like raindrops forming a swift current, all due to gradual progression.
In the ocean of cyclic existence without beginning, one gives rise to the mind of enlightenment,
Arriving at the vajra site, attaining buddhahood is also like this.
With pure mind, upholding the true Dharma, not attached to any meditation,
Not dragged by the objects of desire, always determined and at ease.
The wise should befriend the wise and abandon the ignorant,
Cultivating the body with the virtues of wisdom, such a person is extremely rare!
With faith, seeking the Dharma, always being born in superior places,
Even if falling into danger, the gods will always protect.
In darkness, being a bright lamp, for illness, being a good medicine,
For the poor and destitute, providing precious wealth, for the blind, enabling them to see.
In the turbulent current of the world, being a boat and raft,
If intoxicated, arrogant, and indulgent, one will definitely harm oneself.
This was spoken by the Buddhas of the past, one should fully believe and accept it,
Causing right wisdom to manifest, cultivating without weariness.
Namely, gain, fame, food, drink, bedding, and other such things,
Without the slightest desire or seeking, what can they do to me?
This body is to be abhorred, harmful like an enemy,
Creating all kinds of offenses, always delighting in non-brahmacarya.
Moreover, this body is the basis for various illnesses,
Impure and constantly overflowing, truly a vessel of evil;
Closely dwelling with the mind, without thought or awareness,
In an instant, at the time of death, the evil color is deeply frightening.ğŸ”½The three conditions of life, heat, and consciousness,
Are abandoned simultaneously,
Like a withered tree without knowledge, the form dissolves and foul fluids flow.
When foolish people are in their prime, they are confused and often arrogant and indulgent,
In an instant, not staying for a moment, they change and become decrepit and old.
Relying on wealth and indulgence, creating all kinds of evil karma,
When this person's life is about to end, they will experience extreme suffering and distress.
Not delighting in the true Dharma, how are they different from non-humans?
Turning their back on the city of nirvana, they dwell in the wrong path.
Extensively cultivating meritorious rewards, they are thus reborn among humans,
And should ride the boat of wisdom to forever cross the ocean of existence.
This body is like a flash of lightning, resembling a gandharva's castle.
How can one repeatedly give rise to joy and anger towards others?
This body is not solid, only temporarily moving,
Constantly deceitful in the mind, how can one avoid the fear of old age and death?
It is the city of illness and disease, the dwelling place of worry and distress,
Also like a field, giving rise to good and bad seeds.
If a person adorns their body with giving, precepts, kindness, and wisdom,
Only this good cause and condition is the foremost and most solid.
It is also said that this body is the basis for the various elements,
If one can skillfully awaken to this, one will quickly attain liberation.
This clarifies that one's own body and elements are falsely and forcefully discriminated,
If one delights in the aggregates and elements of others, one is foolish and has no way out.
If externally one possesses various wealth,
But internally the elements are not tranquil, if one skillfully understands the body, one will be able to escape all suffering.
Because of guarding one's own wealth, one further increases suffering and distress,
All fears arise accordingly, such as from officials, thieves, water, and fire.
If one stays far away from wealth that is contrary to the Dharma, then there will be no obstacles,
Abandoning it one always obtains peace, while grasping it one will be at fault.
One should truly understand the characteristics of one's own and others' aggregates and elements,
Cultivating concentration and upholding the scriptures, burning up the mass of afflictions.
Therefore, the wise one skillfully observes the body,
Having already clarified the nature of that realm, this is called the liberated one.
If a person always gives rise to thirst and craving for the five desires,
Because their mind is agitated and disturbed, all evils follow and arise.
If one sees the color of a woman and delights in attachment without temporary abandonment,
Not realizing their impermanence, all evils follow and arise.
Because of that greed and delusion, birth and death increase and grow,
Ordinary beings do not understand, all evils follow and arise.
Always delighting in heedlessness, life is not long,
Without correct wisdom and contemplation, all evils follow and arise.
Greed and desire are insatiable, extravagant clothing and indulgence in adorning the body,
Giving rise to agitation and shamelessness, all evils follow and arise.
Always being defiled by the six sense objects, pulled by the five desires,
Confused about the three times and lacking knowledge, all evils follow and arise.
Delighting in one's own relatives, not knowing one will perish,
Looking back with a mind of anger, all evils follow this.
Formerly indulging in the objects of desire, then becoming a later fault,
Because the mind is not tranquil, all evils follow this.
Enjoying that wealth and happiness, affection suddenly breaks apart,
Not investigating the cause of previous suffering, all evils follow this.
Confused by the delusion of desire, like a fish thrown on land,
Bound and unable to escape, all evils follow this.
Foolish people always love and cling, not knowing the faults of desire,
Confused by the darkness of delusion, all evils follow this.
Accumulating many favorites, going alone when life ends,
Bound by the snare of karma, all evils follow this.
Confused and losing the right path, not knowing the three realms at all,
Not guarding the sense faculties, all evils follow along with this.
In those with precepts and those without, delighting in causing harm,
Destroying the true Dharma, all evils follow along with this.
Regarding offenses, blessings, harm, and benefit, hearing them is like being deaf and mute,
Like a foolish child playing games, all evils follow along with this.
Abandoning the peaceful gardens and forests, springs and other excellent places,
Delighting in attachment to play and idleness, all evils follow along with this.
Departing from the mountain valleys, palaces, and pure lotus ponds,
Due to craving those desires, all evils follow along with this.
Although enjoying fine food and drink, lacking radiance, luster, and majestic virtue,
Engaging in the causes of unwholesome actions, all evils follow along with this.
Thus, these foolish people never give rise to awareness,
Blown by the winds of karma, they revolve in the three realms.
Some are born in superior realms, but fall due to negligence,
Because of laziness and delusion, they are unable to sever faults.
If one abandons the five desires, one attains the highest peace and security,
Like the buddhas and sages, without greed or worry or distress.
Cultivating in the beginning, middle, and end, liberated from all defilements,
One will attain the honored sage, the foremost tranquil bliss.
If one delights in the five desires, one will fall into evil realms,
They have no other ability, only inviting suffering in return.
Therefore, what can the wise person be attached to in desires?
They become the cause of cyclic existence, and one will definitely experience all kinds of pain.
Perhaps dwelling on the jeweled peaks of the heavens, in gardens, forests, and pure ponds,
Due to play and delusion, one becomes attached and falls from there.
In the heavens, on the wondrous golden mountain, with lapis lazuli peaks,
Due to creating unwholesome karma, one falls from there.
The jeweled trees in the heavens, with clear springs surrounding them,
Due to the causes and conditions of greed and desire, one falls from there.
The jeweled groves in the heavens, fragrant seas, and delightful pleasures,
Violating the precepts and leaving behind all goodness, one falls from there.
The wonderful music in the heavens, upon hearing it, can please the mind,
But due to indulging in it and wasting time, one falls from there.
If the mind gives rise to attachment, the objects of desire always appear before one,
Without right wisdom and contemplation, what causes can one obtain peace and joy?
Like a child lacking knowledge, how can one cultivate a little merit,
Having fallen from there, one will personally experience the retribution for one's karma.
If a person creates unwholesomeness, yet seeks pleasant results,
Those causes are dissimilar, the foolish person's mind falsely turns.
In generosity, morality, and right wisdom, they do not cultivate practice,
Foolish people attached to desires are devoured by death.
Lacking wisdom, confused about the fruits of karma, they always commit evil deeds,
Foolish people attached to desires are devoured by death.
Burned by the fire of craving, they do not know the suffering of cyclic existence,
Foolish people attached to desires are devoured by death.
Due to the bonds of emotional attachment, they give rise to the suffering of separation,
When foolish people are like this, they are devoured by death.
Not fearing cyclic existence, their minds run to forms and objects,
Foolish people attached to desires are devoured by death.
Giving rise to the fear of illness and suffering, yet unable to be disgusted with it,
Foolish people attached to desires are devoured by death.
For those evil friends who go on the perilous path of cyclic existence,ğŸ”½...
The foolish one who is attached to desires is devoured by death.
The mind gives rise to wrong thoughts, going against right principles,
The foolish one who is attached to desires is devoured by death.
Engaging in unrighteous conduct, creating the fear of birth and death,
The foolish one who is attached to desires is devoured by death.
Always speaking defiled words, the mind is unaware of sin and merit,
The foolish one who is attached to desires is devoured by death.
Due to habitual craving, one does not delight in the true Dharma,
The foolish one who is attached to desires is devoured by death.
Seeking happiness for oneself, causing harm to the Dharma,
The foolish one who is attached to desires is devoured by death.
One should focus the mind single-pointedly, always cultivating pure karma,
Abandoning all unwholesome deeds, this is called a wise one.
If the gods are attached to pleasure, and do not enjoy cultivating giving and precepts,
They always give rise to a mind of heedlessness, and will certainly fall down.
There is also a heavenly jeweled mountain, adorned with various treasures,
With lapis lazuli peaks, equal to Mount Sumeru.
If the gods are newly born, presently dwelling, or about to perish,
If they give rise to a mind of heedlessness, they will revolve there.
That ground is all pure and clean, with cool breezes rising from the forests and trees,
If they give rise to a mind of heedlessness, they will revolve there.
There are wonderful lotus ponds, with golden leaves and lapis lazuli stems,
If they give rise to a mind of heedlessness, they will revolve there.
There are clear and excellent flowing rivers, with jeweled birds all flying and gathering,
If they give rise to a mind of heedlessness, they will revolve there.
There are the most wonderful palanquins, with multi-storied towers extremely tall and excellent,
If one gives rise to a mind of heedlessness, one will be carried away by it and revolve in samsara.
Such a revolving appearance is all due to delusion towards the objects of desire.
How can one be called a human if the mind does not give rise to aversion and abandonment?
If one delights in practicing heedlessness, one will increase one's revolving in samsara.
If one does not depart from this, one will surely experience great suffering.
Butchers bind together a herd of animals, not allowing them to scatter.
How can one escape when one's relatives accumulate on one's body?
Moreover, those heavenly multitudes always cling to various pleasures.
Not knowing the causes of arising and ceasing, those heavens are like fools.
Thus, those sentient beings are bound by heedlessness.
Extremely increased in delusion, they reach death without awakening.
The mind always creates evil, and is subdued by death.
The fire of desire constantly burns, only increasing regret.
Due to delighting in practicing non-dharma, one definitely enters saá¹ƒsÄra,
At the time of death there, one is extremely frightened and has no savior.
Not contemplating wholesome dharmas, always delighting in joyful gatherings,
Suddenly and suddenly going against, one then experiences the suffering of separation.
Day and night shorten one's lifespan, in a mere moment,
If the fear of death appears before one, one should know that there is no escape.
The wise one sees birth and cessation, and then gives rise to sighs and praises,
Abandoning heedlessness and foolishness, one attains the purity of freedom from defilements.
Contemplating the characteristics of one's own and others' cessation, how can one create various evils?
If the mind is free from faults, one will attain the bliss of tranquility.
Heedfulness is supreme, this is what the TathÄgata has said.
If a person realizes impermanence, then they will abandon all that is unwholesome.
Exhausting the limits of happiness, all is impermanent,
If one gives rise to self-love, one should know to abandon it.
This fear of death is terrifying, swift, and difficult to guard against.
In the midst of play and laughter, one suddenly passes away.
This law of cessation is equal, pervading everywhere.
Not understanding this, one is truly a fool.
Whether young or old, poor or wealthy,
Whether at home or gone forth, one is seized by death.
Whether happy or suffering, virtuous or non-virtuous,
Whether of pure conduct or impure conduct, one is seized by death.
Whether upholding precepts or violating them, wise or foolish,
Even the honored and the lowly, one is seized by death.
Whether gods or hell beings, hungry ghosts or animals,
Whether awake or confused, one is seized by death.
If born in the desire realm, or dwelling in the form realm,
The formless realm is also like this, bound by death.
This body is invaded by old age and sickness, like a staff, rope, whip, or bondage,
That death has great strength, among the masses there is no compassionate protection.
There are various kinds of fear, the fear of death is extremely dangerous and evil,
The devas are blinded by delusion, in the face of this there is crying and laughter.
Falling from the heavens and sinking, there is the suffering of separation,
Or falling into hell, that suffering has no end.
Experiencing the bliss of the heavens, only extinction gives rise to the suffering of sorrow,
Like poison mixed with delicious flavors, therefore one should abandon it.
When the devas' blessings are about to end, their relatives all abandon them,
When they are about to fall, this suffering has no equal.
Because their blessings diminish, like a lamp that goes out when the oil is exhausted,
At the end of this life, it only increases their distress.
Entangled by desire and love, with a worried and agitated mind,
Speaking slowly, with trembling body, this is the fear of their downfall.
Always attached to that pleasure, deceived by desire,
If temporarily separated, they give rise to suffering and distress.
The suffering of the devas falling is lighter than that of hell,
In the sixteen parts, it does not reach even one of them.
The fear of perishing among the devas, the worry of death among humans,
Having seen this, one should not be disgusted with it, let alone the fire of cyclic existence.
Due to attachment to pleasure and loss, one should know the impermanence of the world,
If one awakens to that cause, one should create all good in the mind.
The high will certainly fall, the worldly number will eventually end,
What is combined will separate, death is the limit of life.
All phenomena are impermanent, arising and ceasing,
Where has the triple world ever seen birth without cessation?
Either one is born into another family, or one perishes in the womb,
Or one follows and turns back and forth, or one performs sexual activities,
Just as one sees the light of the sun, having risen, it will certainly set,
All who are born, having ceased, immediately abide as before.
The foolish do not understand that their pleasure arises and ceases,
Lacking the means of escape, later they will only guard death.
One should seek that which is permanent and blissful, diligently cultivating goodness before it perishes,
In accordance with the practice of the true Dharma, this is said to be for the wise.
Impermanence is also uncertain,ğŸ”½The other world turns difficult, the Buddha speaks of the causes of samsara,
This alone is the truth.ğŸ”½That is to say, in each and every arising,
One repeatedly falls into cessation,
Because the gods are attached to pleasure, they often give rise to arrogance.
Moreover, in the heavens, when one's life ends one experiences suffering,
Except for the hells, no suffering is equal to this.
Because of being attached to the five desires, one does not know about one's own decline,
In this way, how can a foolish person escape old age and death?
Experiencing birth and death in the cycle of rebirth, their number is immeasurable,
Not giving rise to a mind of renunciation, they deceive themselves.
Those who dwell high are bound to be in danger, those who hoard treasures will be lacking,
æ©æ„› will part ways, those who are born will all return to death.
Having been born, one immediately grows up, youthful appearance does not linger for a moment,
Suddenly one is impermanent, the nature of birth is like this.
Not taking up merit, one is bound by objects,
Because of greed, love, and delusion, at the time of death there is no savior.
There are also wondrous jeweled peaks, all adorned and complete,
With various kinds of lotus flowers, forests and trees extremely delightful;
There are various rivers and ponds, with water birds all relying on them;
There are various wondrous famous flowers, adorned with various jewels;
There are the most supreme palaces, all made of precious treasures,ğŸ”½The kalpa trees emit golden light, with leaves spread out in the color of vaidurya,
The nikula trees have silver light interspersed,
The lotus buds are all in full bloom, with bees like musical instruments,
There are the most wondrous necklaces, skillfully crafted and incomparably excellent,
The fruits of past cultivation in the human world are all as one wishes.
Those gods attached to pleasure, do not realize their impermanence,
Like a city of gandharvas, like an illusion, a bubble, or foam.
Desire is like a blazing fire, relying on it will lead to destruction,
Because of this, they die and drift in the ocean of existence.
In the pleasures of the five desires, they enjoy them without satiation,
When they perish, they are burned by them, and all the gods depart.
Those with much desire and no shame are the worst of the contemptible,
The gods indulge in delusion, and the demon of death takes advantage of them.
Whether gods, humans, asuras, yakshas, dragons, spirits, and so forth,
Are bound by the snare of death, there is no one who can save them.
Up to pervading the three realms, all are grasped by death,
Because of firmly clinging to greed and delusion, how can they attain liberation?
The gods, due to attachment to pleasure, experience hundreds of thousands of fears of death,
Objects are like dry firewood, and their death is like a raging fire.
If one sees the passing away of others, why is one not awakened oneself?
When suffering from illness and about to die, one personally experiences the retribution of one's karma.
Indulging in carelessness and defiling the mind, one becomes attached to the objects of desire,
Not realizing their impermanence, such is the nature of birth.
If one delights in careless conduct and constantly pursues sensual pleasures,
They are similar to poison, pursued by the soldiers of death.
Neither spells, wondrous medicines, nor powerful asuras,
Being dragged by the rope of death, none of them can save.
Having eyes obscured by the dust of craving, one is completely unaware,
Those beings attached to desire, only death is their refuge.
If one delights in craving and desires much pleasure,
Not giving rise to a mind of renunciation, one is not far from death.
The messengers of Yama, powerful and unassailable,
Suddenly appear before one, and one immediately experiences great terror.
Abandoning the heavenly jeweled mountains, the sublime scenery of forests and springs,
Falling from there, one experiences the fruits of one's own karma.
Delighting in play, one experiences desires without satiation,
Thirsty, deluded by craving, falling, unable to save oneself.
Just as seeing smoke in the distance, one knows the fire is not far,
When the signs of decline appear, one will certainly fall.
What is born must perish, there is no illness that can be temporarily at ease,
Youth is invaded by old age, prosperity suddenly changes to decline;
Enmity and love are separated, union does not last long,
All dharmas are originally impermanent, as taught by the Perfectly Enlightened One.
The dharmas of self and other arising and perishing, these two always follow and transform,
Perishing and then arising again, definitely abiding in this way.
In a moment, the little merit of a foolish person is immediately exhausted,
Therefore, the true heroes quickly cultivate the Dharma of self-mastery.
Youthful appearance does not last long, and life also follows in its demise.
Always remove thoughts of negligence and fully cultivate all wholesome [deeds].
The gods who possess wisdom understand the arising and ceasing of moments,
and diligently cultivate meritorious deeds, attaining true permanence.
There are also marvelous towers, with dense leaves creating a clear shade,
and vines sprouting extraordinary flowers, fragrant and surrounding them.
There are supreme and wondrous towers, adorned with various treasures,
with golden rivers flowing clear springs, and precious things filling the steps and railings.
All are due to wholesome karma, but in the end they will not last long,
just like Mount Sumeru, which also disintegrates at the end of the eon.
Moreover, those heavenly beings give rise to arrogance and negligence,
not contemplating impermanence, they fall in an instant.
Those sentient beings in the heavens attain mastery over the five desires,
Having experienced much happiness, they will certainly sink into evil destinies.
If the body, sense faculties, and consciousness are oppressed without time or place,
That suffering is extremely difficult and painful, and one does not know its quantity.
Relying on one's many dependents, one gives rise to the notion of permanence,
When one is about to fall, one will then experience the suffering of separation.
With regard to one's attendants and servants, they will all abandon one at the same time,
Due to the increase of delusion, one will be unaware until death.
When those gods are about to perish, their faculties and consciousness will only be sorrow and suffering,
Seeing this fall, they and I will be no different.
These three realms are false, and all phenomena are conditioned,
Revolving like a wheel, not solid like a mass of foam.
This body is like a mass of foam, attached to bedding and clothing;
This mind is like a wheel, delighting in union and movement.
Neither gods, humans, yakshas, asuras, nor garudas,
Only one's own good karma can save one at the time of death.
Even in the future, the fear of death is deeply terrifying,
If one does not cultivate superior causes, regret will be of no benefit.
This is a contemptible realm, able to give rise to much desire and pleasure,
Due to lack of wisdom and foolishness, one does not know the limit of life.
Who are these relatives?
Who is this happiness?

Dragged by the rope of death, following karma and going far away.
Like water leaping in the sky, the momentum falls and scatters,
Gathering together, there is separation, transmigrating and revolving each in their own way.
